Description: Carved panel; cedarwood; from a door; oblong; the Entry into Jerusalem; above is Christ, full-face, riding sideways upon an ass; he has the cruciferous nimbus with the addition of a small cross above the head, and his garments are richly embroidered; behind him is visible the top of a palm-tree, which rises from the lower part of the panel; in it are seated four small figures cutting branches; below is a group of Jewish spectators of both sexes.
Curator's comments: On the el-Muʿallaqah church and it furnishing: E. Maglaque, "Devotional and Artistic Responses to Contested Space in Old Cairo: The Case of Al-Mu’allakah", in: M. Gharipour, ed. Sacred Precincts: Non-Muslim Sites in Islamic Societies (Leiden 2014) 143-57; M. Immerzeel, The Narrow Way to Heaven: Identity and Identities in the Art of Middle Eastern Christianity (Louvain 2017) 69-76.
Bibliographic references: Dalton 1901 / Catalogue of Early Christian Antiquities and Objects from the Christian East in the Department of British and Medieval Antiquities and Ethnography of the British Museum (986)
Paris 2000 / L'art copte en Égypte 2000 ans de christianisme: Exposition présentée à l’Institut du monde arabe, Paris (no.184, p.176-77)
Hunt 1989 / The al-Muʿallaqa Doors Reconstructed: An Early Fourteenth-Century Sanctuary Screen from Old Cairo
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2015, Oct 29 – 2016, Feb 7. British Museum, Room 35. Egypt: Faith after the Pharoahs 2008-2009 25 Oct-22 Mar, London, Royal Academy of Arts, Byzantium 330-1453 AD 2004 15 Mar-5 Jul, USA, New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Byzantium; Faith and Power 2000 30 Sep-2001 7 Jan, France, La Clape, Musée de l’Ephebe, L’art copte en Egypte 2000 15 May-3 Sep, France, Paris, Institut du Monde Arabe, Coptic Art
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Charles H A Schefer
